IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
MSP marked vehicle F-40 is equipped with a mobile recording device, and body worn camera footage captured the incident.

Defendant: Kenneth Winfield Henson

Date of Birth: 03/17/1954                            

Date of Arrest: 10/07/2023

Time of Arrest: 2250 hours

DUI#: 23-137

CERTIFICATES AND TRAINING
  • Trained in administering standardized field sobriety tests through the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
  • Advanced DUI training by the Maryland State Police State Police Impaired Driving Effort (S.P.I.D.R.E.) team.
  • Advanced Roadside Impairment Detection Enforcement (A.R.I.D.E.) course taught by the Maryland State Police Chemical Test for Alcohol Unit (C.T.A.U).

VEHICLE IN MOTION (PHASE 1)

On Saturday October 7, 2023 at approximately 2232 hours I, Trooper Starr #7289, was on routine patrol in my MSP marked vehicle F-40 in the area of the North East Sunoco located at 2391 Pulaski Highway. At this time a BOLO (Be On the Look Out) was given for a gold Cadillac displaying Maryland registration 7EA9098 traveling westbound on Pulaski Highway in the area of the North East Domino’s Pizza located at 2328 Pulaski Highway. The caller, which contacted the MSP North East Barrack, stated that she was behind the gold Cadillac and observed it to be driving recklessly and was struggling to maintain a single lane. The caller also stated that she witnessed the vehicle lose control and strike the curb on Pulaski Highway across from the Domino’s Pizza.

As I waited in the Sunoco parking lot for the vehicle to pass my location, I observed it sitting stationary in lane one at the location where the caller stated it struck the curb. Approximately five seconds later the vehicle continued traveling westbound Pulaski Highway approaching North East Road. I then positioned my cruiser directly behind the vehicle in the left turn lane at Pulaski Highway and North East Road. I confirmed the Maryland registration to be 7EA9098.

The vehicle then made a left turn onto North Mauldin Avenue and I observed it cross onto the white solid line on the right shoulder. Approximately 1/10th of a mile later I observed the vehicle drift over the right shoulder solid fog line again and almost strike the curb. The vehicle then drifted back into the lane and started approaching the center double yellow lane dividers. For the safety of the driver and other drivers on the roadway I activated my emergency equipment and performed a traffic stop on the vehicle at North Mauldin Avenue prior to West Cecil Avenue.

PERSONAL CONTACT (PHASE 2)

I approached the vehicle from the passenger side and made contact with the driver and sole occupant of the vehicle who was identified as Kenneth Winfield Henson (B/M DOB 03/17/1954). I introduced myself and informed Henson for the reason of the stop. I then requested his license and registration. Henson struggled to retrieve his license from his wallet and fumbled with the other cards in it as he tried to remove his license. Henson also provided me with a previous traffic warning instead of the vehicle registration which I had to remind him to locate. He then attempted to provide me with the vehicle insurance instead of the registration which I again advised him that I needed. As I communicated with Henson, I detected his speech to be extremely slurred, and he struggled to form complete sentences and was responding incoherently. I also observed his eyes to be extremely glassy. I then requested the keys to the vehicle and asked him to step outside of the vehicle.

When he exited, I observed Henson stumble and it appeared he struggled to gain his balance. Once outside of the vehicle I detected a strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from Henson’s person. I asked Henson where he was coming from and he stated he was coming from his home in Elkton and was going to his nephew’s house in North East. I asked him where his nephew lives, but he was unable to provide me an address. I asked him how many alcoholic beverages he consumed prior to driving and he stated he had “a couple drinks”. Henson stated he had a beer two hours ago, but was unable to provide what else he drank. I asked Henson on a scale of 0-10 how impaired he felt and he stated he was a 3/10. The entire time I communicated with Henson I also observed him swaying front to back and left to right. Based on all above observations, I requested Henson to complete a series of standardized field sobriety tests to ensure he was safe to drive.

PRE-ARREST SCREENING (PHASE 3)

The evaluation was performed on the right shoulder of North Mauldin Avenue. The surface was dry, mostly level, and free from any obvious debris. The weather was cool and approximately 60 degrees, and the area was lit by street lights, vehicle lights, and my flashlight. Henson appeared to be in good physical condition and did not display any injuries, or any limb ailments (reference below for further information regarding Henson’s health and injury status.)

I asked Henson the following questions:

Medications- Five different medications for high blood pressure (Henson was unsure what specific medications he takes).

Glasses/Contacts- Henson wears glasses and did not wear them during the tests.

Physical Injuries- Henson stated he had a bad back.

Medical conditions- High blood pressure.

HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS (6/6 CLUES OBSERVED)

The first test given was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus test. The tip of my pen was used as the stimulus and held approximately 12-15 inches from Henson’s eyes. He was instructed to look straight ahead, keeping his head still while following and focusing on the tip of the stimulus with his eyes until told to stop. Henson’s pupils were equal in size and showed equal tracking and no resting nystagmus was observed.

(AS HENSON COMPLETED THE HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS TEST, I OBSERVED HIM SWAY BACK AND FORTH AND I ALSO HAD TO REMIND HIM SEVERAL TIMES TO FOLLOW THE STIMULUS WITH HIS EYES ONLY).

Henson displayed the following clues:
  1. Lack of smooth pursuit- Displayed in both eyes.
  2. Distinct and sustained nystagmus as maximum deviation- Displayed in both eyes.
  3. Onset of nystagmus prior to 45 degrees- Displayed in both eyes.
WALK AND TURN (4/8 CLUES OBSERVED)

Prior to Henson performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. Henson was instructed to place his right foot directly in front of his left foot and touch heel to toe. Henson was instructed and demonstrated to place his hands flat at his side and to remain in that position until told to begin. Henson was advised to take nine (9) steps on a straight line touching heel to toe on every step. Henson was instructed to keep his hands flat at his side, keep his eyes focused on his feet, and to count every step aloud. On the ninth step, Henson was explained and demonstrated to keep his lead foot on the line, and to take a series of small steps around his lead foot until completely turned around. Henson was again explained and demonstrated how the second series of nine (9) steps were to be performed. Henson was instructed to keep his hands down by his side, look down at his feet, and count each step out loud. I asked Henson if he understood the test and he stated that he did. (FOOTWEAR: HENSON COMPLETED THE TEST IN HIS SNEAKERS.)

Instructional Stage:
  1. Cannot keep balance- Henson attempted and failed several times to get into the instructional stage position. I subsequently requested Henson to just stand comfortably while I explained the instructions.
  2. Begins test too soon- Henson started walking right when I began giving instructions.
Walking Stage (1st nine steps):
  1. Heel-to-toe- Henson failed to take heel-to-toe steps on steps 1-9.
Turn:
  1. Henson did not complete the turn as instructed.
Walking Stage (2nd nine steps):
  1. Heel-to-toe- Henson failed to take heel-to-toe steps on steps 1-9.
ONE LEG STAND (2/4 CLUES)

Prior to Henson performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. Henson was instructed to stand with his feet together and hands down by his side while the instructions were given and during the test. When instructed to begin, he was to raise the foot of his choice off the ground approximately 6 inches. While his leg was raised, he was to keep his leg straight, watch his foot, and to count out loud by thousands (one thousand-one, one thousand-two) and to continue the test until told to stop. I asked Henson if he understood the test and he stated that he did. (FOOTWEAR: HENSON COMPLETED THE TEST IN HIS SNEAKERS. HENSON BALANCED ON HIS RIGHT FOOT.)

Balance and count stage:

Seconds 0-10
  1. Henson placed his foot on the ground every other second as he was unable to keep his balance on one foot for longer than a second.
  2. Henson swayed front to back and left to right on counts 1-10.
Seconds 11-20
  1. Henson placed his foot on the ground every other second as he was unable to keep his balance on one foot for longer than a second.
  2. Henson swayed front to back and left to right on counts 11-20.
Seconds 21-30
  1. Henson placed his foot on the ground every other second as he was unable to keep his balance on one foot for longer than a second.
  2. Henson swayed front to back and left to right on counts 21-25.
HENSON STATED HE COULD NOT PERFORM THE TEST DUE TO HIS BACK PAIN, AND SUBSEQUENTLY STOPPED THE TEST AT 25 SECONDS.

ARREST

Based on the following, I had reason to believe Henson was driving a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol:
  1. Henson struggled to maintain a single lane multiple times and almost struck a curb while I followed behind him.
  2. Henson later admitted that he struck a curb while traveling on Pulaski Highway prior to my observation. Reference attached photograph of the vehicle damage which is consistent with the claim.
  3. Glassy eyes.
  4. Extremely slurred speech.
  5. Could not formulate complete sentences and was speaking incoherently.
  6. Poor fine motor skills while locating license and registration.
  7. Poor balance.
  8. Admission to having a couple alcoholic beverages prior to driving.
  9. Stated he was a 3/10 on an impairment scale.
  10. Strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from Henson’s person.
  11. Unsatisfactory completion of the standardized field sobriety tests.
Based on my observations I arrested Henson for driving under the influence of alcohol at approximately 2250 hours. Henson was then transported back to the North East barrack for processing.

PBT

Henson was not offered to take the PBT.

20 MINUTE OBSERVATION PERIOD

I checked Henson’s mouth at approximately 2254 hours, and observed him not to have anything to eat or drink.

INTOXIMETER RESULT

Once back at the barrack Henson was read the DR-15 advice of rights, and he refused to submit to the intoximeter test.

Henson was issued appropriate citations and paperwork. He was advised not to drive for 12 hours, and was released to a sober driver.

All events occurred in Cecil County, Maryland.
